The main types of throat cancer are laryngeal and pharyngeal. There are several other subtypes that are slightly less common. - Nasopharynx: Upper part of throat behind the nose. - Oropharynx: Middle part of throat behind the mouth. - Larynx: AKA the voice box. - Hypopharynx: Lower part of throat just above the larynx. Note: Esophageal cancer—which starts in the esophagus—is not considered a throat cancer.

These two words both have associations w: The main types of throat cancer are laryngeal and pharyngeal, as illustrated in the first image. Laryngeal cancer affects the upper part of the throat behind the nose, while pharyngeal cancer impacts the middle part of the throat behind the mouth. Additionally, there is a type called hypopharyngeal cancer, which affects the lower part of the throat just above the larynx. Eosphenageal cancer, starting in the esophagus, is not considered a type of throat cancer. The second image shows a hand pointing at a chalkboard with the mathematical equation "1 + 1 = 2," indicating a focus on basic arithmetic.
